snippet: Fueled in part by efforts to qualify for grant programs or No Child Left Behind waivers, 36 states and the District of Columbia have introduced new policies.
abstract: New teacher evaluation policies have been introduced by 36 states and District of Columbia in past three years, as part of efforts to qualify for Obama administration's Race to the Top federal grant program or waivers from toughest conditions of No Child Left Behind; attention had mainly focused on evaluation systems that based portion of teacher's rating from student performance on standardized tests, but new state policies also include a component based on classroom observations.
lead_paragraph: Fueled in part by efforts to qualify for grant programs or No Child Left Behind waivers, 36 states and the District of Columbia have introduced new policies.

headline.seo: Seeking Aid, More Districts Change Teacher Evaluations
headline.main: Seeking Aid, School Districts Change Teacher Evaluations
headline.print_headline: Seeking Federal Aid, More School Districts Introduce New Ways To Evaluate Teachers
